channel.title: Global News Podcast
channel.description: The day’s top stories from BBC News. Delivered twice a day on weekdays, daily at weekends
channel.itunes:summary: The day’s top stories from BBC News. Delivered twice a day on weekdays, daily at weekends
channel.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Former Pakistan PM Imran Khan says a gunman thought he had killed him
item.description: In his first comments since the recent attack, Pakistan's former PM says two gunmen tried to kill him. Also: mass sackings begin at Twitter, and are we prepared if aliens contact us from a distant planet?
item.itunes:subtitle: Sitting in a wheelchair, Mr Khan spoke of the gun attack in Wazirabad
item.itunes:summary: In his first comments since the recent attack, Pakistan's former PM says two gunmen tried to kill him. Also: mass sackings begin at Twitter, and are we prepared if aliens contact us from a distant planet?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine war: Zelensky accuses Russia of ‘energy terrorism’
item.description: Ukraine’s President said 4.5 million people were left without power following Russian attacks; as the two sides prepare for a battle over the southern city of Kherson. Also: The German Chancellor breaks from the rest of the West to hold talks with China's leader Xi Jinping, and the rare goose that Hawaii is turning the lights out to protect.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ukraine’s President said 4.5 million people left without power following Russian attacks
item.itunes:summary: Ukraine’s President said 4.5 million people were left without power following Russian attacks; as the two sides prepare for a battle over the southern city of Kherson. Also: The German Chancellor breaks from the rest of the West to hold talks with China's leader Xi Jinping, and the rare goose that Hawaii is turning the lights out to protect.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Imran Khan survives deadly Pakistan rally shooting
item.description: Pakistan's former prime minister remains in hospital after the shooting in Wazirabad. Also: Glencore ordered to pay millions over Africa oil bribes, and almost half of UK workers have been mocked for their accents.
item.itunes:subtitle: His allies claim the attack was an assassination attempt
item.itunes:summary: Pakistan's former prime minister remains in hospital after the shooting in Wazirabad. Also: Glencore ordered to pay millions over Africa oil bribes, and almost half of UK workers have been mocked for their accents.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Pakistan's former prime minister, Imran Khan, shot and wounded
item.description: Senior aide said it was "an attempt to kill him". Also; UN warning over glacier threat and the World Cup accused of greenwashing.
item.itunes:subtitle: Senior aide said it was "an attempt to kill him"
item.itunes:summary: Senior aide said it was "an attempt to kill him". Also; UN warning over glacier threat and the World Cup accused of greenwashing.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Truce agreed to halt Ethiopia's civil war
item.description: Both sides agreed to stop their conflict in Ethiopia which has led to a humanitarian crisis. Also: Parkland school gunman sentenced to life in US prison, and the oldest voter in India.
item.itunes:subtitle: The African Union has called the deal a new 'dawn'
item.itunes:summary: Both sides agreed to stop their conflict in Ethiopia which has led to a humanitarian crisis. Also: Parkland school gunman sentenced to life in US prison, and the oldest voter in India.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Israel elections: Netanyahu set for comeback with far right's help
item.description: The former Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is on the brink of returning to power, after partial results show he is on course to win a majority in parliament with the help of the far right. Also: a sharp escalation in military tension between North and South Korea, as both sides fire missiles into the sea; and how five lions escaped from a zoo in Australia.
item.itunes:subtitle: The former Israeli Prime Minister is on the brink of returning to power.
item.itunes:summary: The former Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is on the brink of returning to power, after partial results show he is on course to win a majority in parliament with the help of the far right. Also: a sharp escalation in military tension between North and South Korea, as both sides fire missiles into the sea; and how five lions escaped from a zoo in Australia.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Bolsonaro says he 'will respect the constitution'
item.description: The Brazilian President breaks days of silence following Sunday's poll defeat. Also: Benjamin Netanyahu could be about to make another comeback following Israeli elections, and, why the Italian government isn't raving about raves.
item.itunes:subtitle: Brazilian President breaks days of silence following poll defeat
item.itunes:summary: The Brazilian President breaks days of silence following Sunday's poll defeat. Also: Benjamin Netanyahu could be about to make another comeback following Israeli elections, and, why the Italian government isn't raving about raves.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: South Korean police admit responsibility for crush
item.description: Police chief says not enough was done to prevent it. Also: The Greek coast guard is coordinating a search- and- rescue operation in the Aegean sea for dozens of missing migrants, and Brazilian police have been taking action to end blockades by lorry drivers who support the outgoing president, Jair Bolsonaro.
item.itunes:subtitle: Police chief says not enough was done to prevent it
item.itunes:summary: Police chief says not enough was done to prevent it. Also: The Greek coast guard is coordinating a search- and- rescue operation in the Aegean sea for dozens of missing migrants, and Brazilian police have been taking action to end blockades by lorry drivers who support the outgoing president, Jair Bolsonaro.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: President Bolsonaro still silent following election defeat
item.description: Growing unease that he may contest the outcome as Argentina's leader arrives in Brazil to congratulate Lula. Also: Ukrainian engineers scramble to restore electricity to large areas of the country after a wave of Russian missile strikes, and, a saucy new theory about how our ancient cousins, the Neanderthals, died out forty thousand years ago.
item.itunes:subtitle: Increasing unease in Brazil that he may contest the outcome.
item.itunes:summary: Growing unease that he may contest the outcome as Argentina's leader arrives in Brazil to congratulate Lula. Also: Ukrainian engineers scramble to restore electricity to large areas of the country after a wave of Russian missile strikes, and, a saucy new theory about how our ancient cousins, the Neanderthals, died out forty thousand years ago.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: President Bolsonaro of Brazil yet to acknowledge Lula's victory
item.description: President-elect Lula da Silva has called for unity, as world leaders congratulate him on his narrow victory. Also: Hundreds of people in Iran are charged with rioting in an attempt by the authorities to stop protestors, and how can indigenous people's understanding of the natural world help scientists tackle climate change?
item.itunes:subtitle: President-elect Lula da Silva has called for unity, as world leaders congratulate him
item.itunes:summary: President-elect Lula da Silva has called for unity, as world leaders congratulate him on his narrow victory. Also: Hundreds of people in Iran are charged with rioting in an attempt by the authorities to stop protestors, and how can indigenous people's understanding of the natural world help scientists tackle climate change?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Lula wins Brazil's presidential election
item.description: The narrow victory completes a staggering rehabilitation for the former president who was jailed for corruption. Also: A suspension bridge crowded with pedestrians has collapsed in the Indian state of Gujarat, killing at least 80 people, and to mark Halloween, we hear about the woman who collects recipes from tombstones.
item.itunes:subtitle: The narrow victory completes a staggering rehabilitation for the former president
item.itunes:summary: The narrow victory completes a staggering rehabilitation for the former president who was jailed for corruption. Also: A suspension bridge crowded with pedestrians has collapsed in the Indian state of Gujarat, killing at least 80 people, and to mark Halloween, we hear about the woman who collects recipes from tombstones.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Halloween stampede in Seoul kills dozens
item.description: Nearly 150 people died in the crush in a busy South Korean bar district which was full of revellers. Also: Russia says it's suspending global grain exports from Ukraine following a drone attack on Russian ships in occupied Crimea, and the footballers wives trial that just keeps on giving: Wagatha Christie the play!
item.itunes:subtitle: Nearly 150 people died in the crush in a busy bar district
item.itunes:summary: Nearly 150 people died in the crush in a busy South Korean bar district which was full of revellers. Also: Russia says it's suspending global grain exports from Ukraine following a drone attack on Russian ships in occupied Crimea, and the footballers wives trial that just keeps on giving: Wagatha Christie the play!
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Brazil heads to the polls
item.description: Far-right President Jair Bolsonaro faces former leftist leader Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. In this special edition of the Global News Podcast, Nick Miles is in Rio de Janeiro hearing how people living in the country's largest favela are split between the candidates. We also hear about the accusations and misinformation on the campaign trail.
item.itunes:subtitle: Far-right President Jair Bolsonaro faces former leftist leader Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva
item.itunes:summary: Far-right President Jair Bolsonaro faces former leftist leader Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. In this special edition of the Global News Podcast, Nick Miles is in Rio de Janeiro hearing how people living in the country's largest favela are split between the candidates. We also hear about the accusations and misinformation on the campaign trail.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Pelosi hammer attacker shouted 'where is Nancy?'
item.description: The leading US Democrat's husband was attacked by an intruder in their Californian home. Also: Elon Musk clears out Twitter bosses in $44bn deal; the Rock and Roll legend Jerry Lee Lewis dies aged 87.
item.itunes:subtitle: The suspect is facing charges including attempted murder
item.itunes:summary: The leading US Democrat's husband was attacked by an intruder in their Californian home. Also: Elon Musk clears out Twitter bosses in $44bn deal; the Rock and Roll legend Jerry Lee Lewis dies aged 87.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Imran Khan leads procession to demand early elections
item.description: The former Pakistani leader wants to march with supporters from Lahore to Islamabad. Also: Germany's president warns of hard years ahead, and how bumblebees enjoy themselves.
item.itunes:subtitle: The former Pakistani leader wants to march with supporters from Lahore to Islamabad
item.itunes:summary: The former Pakistani leader wants to march with supporters from Lahore to Islamabad. Also: Germany's president warns of hard years ahead, and how bumblebees enjoy themselves.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Putin says world faces most dangerous decade since WW2
item.description: In a speech, Russia's president claims the West is unable to stay in charge but is "desperately trying" to cling on. Also: live fire used again as Iran protests continue, and Nasa space probes witness big impact on Mars.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Russian leader also sought to justify the invasion of Ukraine
item.itunes:summary: In a speech, Russia's president claims the West is unable to stay in charge but is "desperately trying" to cling on. Also: live fire used again as Iran protests continue, and Nasa space probes witness big impact on Mars.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: World facing 'first truly global energy crisis'
item.description: The International Energy Agency says Russia's invasion of Ukraine will have long-lasting effects on energy supplies and markets. Also, Estonia urges western allies to increase defence spending, and doctors in Germany warn of the dangers of cannabis after suggestions the small amounts of the drug could be legalised.
item.itunes:subtitle: The IEA says Russia's invasion of Ukraine will have lasting effects on energy supplies
item.itunes:summary: The International Energy Agency says Russia's invasion of Ukraine will have long-lasting effects on energy supplies and markets. Also, Estonia urges western allies to increase defence spending, and doctors in Germany warn of the dangers of cannabis after suggestions the small amounts of the drug could be legalised.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Iranian police fire on Mahsa Amini mourners
item.description: Thousands had gathered in the young woman's home city of Saqez to mark 40 days since her death in custody. Also: Putin watches first Russian nuclear drill since invasion of Ukraine, and a dream of growing tea in Orkney becomes reality.
item.itunes:subtitle: Protests have swept across Iran since her death
item.itunes:summary: Thousands had gathered in the young woman's home city of Saqez to mark 40 days since her death in custody. Also: Putin watches first Russian nuclear drill since invasion of Ukraine, and a dream of growing tea in Orkney becomes reality.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US midterm elections: Your questions answered
item.description: Ahead of the US midterm elections, Oliver Conway is joined by Americast's Sarah Smith, Anthony Zurcher and Marianna Spring to discuss the Trump factor, abortion, the role of social media and much more. Will the Republicans sweep the board or can the Democrats hold on to at least one of the houses of Congress? The result is likely to shape American politics for the next two years - and could help determine who ends up in the White House in 2024.
item.itunes:subtitle: We discuss the Trump factor, abortion, the role of social media and much more
item.itunes:summary: Ahead of the US midterm elections, Oliver Conway is joined by Americast's Sarah Smith, Anthony Zurcher and Marianna Spring to discuss the Trump factor, abortion, the role of social media and much more. Will the Republicans sweep the board or can the Democrats hold on to at least one of the houses of Congress? The result is likely to shape American politics for the next two years - and could help determine who ends up in the White House in 2024.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: China accused of illegal police stations in the Netherlands
item.description: Dutch media finds Beijing using service centres to try to silence its opponents. Also: Iranian security forces are reported to have opened fire on thousands of protestors in the home town of Mahsa Amini, who died in custody last month, and six new species of frog have been discovered in Ecuador.
item.itunes:subtitle: Dutch media finds Beijing using service centres to try to silence its opponents
item.itunes:summary: Dutch media finds Beijing using service centres to try to silence its opponents. Also: Iranian security forces are reported to have opened fire on thousands of protestors in the home town of Mahsa Amini, who died in custody last month, and six new species of frog have been discovered in Ecuador.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukrainian refugees asked not to return this winter
item.description: Ukraine's energy sector is struggling to cope after Russian attacks. Also: Britain's new prime minister appoints key members of his cabinet, and the secret sounds of sea animals.
item.itunes:subtitle: More than a third of Ukraine's energy sector has been destroyed
item.itunes:summary: Ukraine's energy sector is struggling to cope after Russian attacks. Also: Britain's new prime minister appoints key members of his cabinet, and the secret sounds of sea animals.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Sunak starts work as British PM
item.description: He said he will 'fix the mistakes' made by his predecessor in his first speech to the nation. Also: Israeli security forces have killed six Palestinians, including several militants, in a raid in the occupied West Bank, and, Oscar-nominated actor Richard E. Grant previews Barbara Streisand's new album.
item.itunes:subtitle: He said he will 'fix mistakes' made by his predecessor in first speech to the nation
item.itunes:summary: He said he will 'fix the mistakes' made by his predecessor in his first speech to the nation. Also: Israeli security forces have killed six Palestinians, including several militants, in a raid in the occupied West Bank, and, Oscar-nominated actor Richard E. Grant previews Barbara Streisand's new album.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: UK appoints first Indian origin PM Rishi Sunak
item.description: Rishi Sunak warns of profound economic challenges ahead and promises to serve with integrity and humility. Also: The US Justice Department has charged 13 Chinese nationals with attempting to steal technology, harassing dissidents and interfering in the prosecution of a telecoms firm, and, hundreds of millions around the world celebrate Diwali.
item.itunes:subtitle: Rishi Sunak warns of profound economic challenges ahead and promises unity.
item.itunes:summary: Rishi Sunak warns of profound economic challenges ahead and promises to serve with integrity and humility. Also: The US Justice Department has charged 13 Chinese nationals with attempting to steal technology, harassing dissidents and interfering in the prosecution of a telecoms firm, and, hundreds of millions around the world celebrate Diwali.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: The UK’s next Prime Minister will be Rishi Sunak
item.description: Rishi Sunak wins UK Conservative party leadership contest as only other contender steps down. Also: meeting those living in recently liberated Kherson in Ukraine, Uganda attempts to contain an Ebola outbreak and sheep flood the streets of Spanish capital Madrid.
item.itunes:subtitle: Rishi Sunak wins UK Conservative party leadership contest as other contender steps down
item.itunes:summary: Rishi Sunak wins UK Conservative party leadership contest as only other contender steps down. Also: meeting those living in recently liberated Kherson in Ukraine, Uganda attempts to contain an Ebola outbreak and sheep flood the streets of Spanish capital Madrid.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: China: Xi gets unprecedented third presidential term
item.description: The Chinese leader cements his grip on power by promoting his allies. Also: Boris Jonson rules out running in the race to become UK prime minister again, and, lost and found - now to be broadcast live on the BBC - a work by the black Canadian American composer Nathaniel Dett.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Chinese leader cements his grip on power by promoting his allies.
item.itunes:summary: The Chinese leader cements his grip on power by promoting his allies. Also: Boris Jonson rules out running in the race to become UK prime minister again, and, lost and found - now to be broadcast live on the BBC - a work by the black Canadian American composer Nathaniel Dett.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Zelensky says Russia 'will not break us'
item.description: The Ukrainian president denounces attacks on key infrastructure that left more than a million without power. Also, the two men expected to be front-runners in the race to become Britain's new prime minister -- Boris Johnson and Rishi Sunak -- hold face-to-face talks, and China's President Xi prepares to be given an unprecedented third term in office.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ukrainian president denounces attacks on infrastructure that left many without power
item.itunes:summary: The Ukrainian president denounces attacks on key infrastructure that left more than a million without power. Also, the two men expected to be front-runners in the race to become Britain's new prime minister -- Boris Johnson and Rishi Sunak -- hold face-to-face talks, and China's President Xi prepares to be given an unprecedented third term in office.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Trump summoned by January 6th committee
item.description: The former president is ordered to testify under oath by 14th November. Also: Giorgia Meloni is to become the first far-right leader in decades to be sworn in as Italian prime minister, and a wild bison is born in Britain for what's thought to be the first time since the Ice Age.
item.itunes:subtitle: The former president is ordered to testify under oath by 14th November
item.itunes:summary: The former president is ordered to testify under oath by 14th November. Also: Giorgia Meloni is to become the first far-right leader in decades to be sworn in as Italian prime minister, and a wild bison is born in Britain for what's thought to be the first time since the Ice Age.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Pakistan's election commission bars Imran Khan from office
item.description: The Election Commission of Pakistan disqualifies the former prime minister, Imran Khan, from holding public office for unlawfully selling state gifts. Also: President Zelensky of Ukraine accuses Russia of planting mines at a dam near the city of Kherson. And how Italians feel about comparisons between the UK and Italy, when it comes to political instability.
item.itunes:subtitle: Imran Khan is accused of not declaring gifts from foreign dignitaries
item.itunes:summary: The Election Commission of Pakistan disqualifies the former prime minister, Imran Khan, from holding public office for unlawfully selling state gifts. Also: President Zelensky of Ukraine accuses Russia of planting mines at a dam near the city of Kherson. And how Italians feel about comparisons between the UK and Italy, when it comes to political instability.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Process begins to elect new British PM
item.description: The resignation of Liz Truss after 45 days in office makes her the shortest-serving Prime Minister in UK history. Also: Ukrainians are being told to prepare for blackouts as Russia increases its attacks on energy plants, and a survey says millions of Chinese people over 60 are planning to go back to work.
item.itunes:subtitle: Candidates need to have the backing of at least 100 MPs
item.itunes:summary: The resignation of Liz Truss after 45 days in office makes her the shortest-serving Prime Minister in UK history. Also: Ukrainians are being told to prepare for blackouts as Russia increases its attacks on energy plants, and a survey says millions of Chinese people over 60 are planning to go back to work.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: British prime minister Liz Truss steps down
item.description: The resignation follows days of chaos in the government. Also: Ukrainian authorities impose energy restrictions across the country, and what is China's 'wolf-warrior diplomacy'?
item.itunes:subtitle: The resignation follows days of chaos in the government
item.itunes:summary: The resignation follows days of chaos in the government. Also: Ukrainian authorities impose energy restrictions across the country, and what is China's 'wolf-warrior diplomacy'?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: British minister resigns in day of chaos at Westminster
item.description: Suella Braverman resigned as Home Secretary and in a letter she criticised the Prime Minister Liz Truss. Also: heightened security measures come into force in Russia as president Putin tries to tighten his control, and could viruses locked away in glaciers pose a threat to wildlife and humans?
item.itunes:subtitle: There were also chaotic scenes in parliament during a vote on fracking
item.itunes:summary: Suella Braverman resigned as Home Secretary and in a letter she criticised the Prime Minister Liz Truss. Also: heightened security measures come into force in Russia as president Putin tries to tighten his control, and could viruses locked away in glaciers pose a threat to wildlife and humans?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: President Putin declares martial law in four regions of Ukraine
item.description: Russian forces start evacuating thousands of civilians from the occupied city of Kherson. Also: crowds welcome returning Iranian climber and a new study says little sleep can cause illness.
item.itunes:subtitle: Russian forces start evacuating thousands of civilians from occupied city of Kherson
item.itunes:summary: Russian forces start evacuating thousands of civilians from the occupied city of Kherson. Also: crowds welcome returning Iranian climber and a new study says little sleep can cause illness.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Russia admits Kherson 'tense' under shelling
item.description: In a rare admission of problems, Russia's infamous army chief in Ukraine, Sergei Surovikin, says residents in Kherson should leave. Also: Ethiopia army seizes three towns in Tigray, and is there a Kimchi crisis in south Korea?
item.itunes:subtitle: Ukrainian troops are hitting the city's infrastructure
item.itunes:summary: In a rare admission of problems, Russia's infamous army chief in Ukraine, Sergei Surovikin, says residents in Kherson should leave. Also: Ethiopia army seizes three towns in Tigray, and is there a Kimchi crisis in south Korea?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine: Zelensky says nearly a third of power stations destroyed
item.description: Ukraine's Civil Defence Service says over a thousand towns and villages without power. Also: teachers and transport workers across France join strike action that's already affected fuel supplies, and the saga of an ancient Japanese toilet accidentally destroyed in a freak accident!
item.itunes:subtitle: Ukraine's Civil Defence Service says over a thousand towns and villages without power
item.itunes:summary: Ukraine's Civil Defence Service says over a thousand towns and villages without power. Also: teachers and transport workers across France join strike action that's already affected fuel supplies, and the saga of an ancient Japanese toilet accidentally destroyed in a freak accident!
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: British prime minister apologises for her mistakes
item.description: The British prime minister Liz Truss says sorry after her chancellor tears up almost all of her tax-cutting agenda. Also: UN chief says Ethiopia war is spiralling out of control, and the BBC at 100.
item.itunes:subtitle: Liz Truss insists she will lead Tories into next election
item.itunes:summary: The British prime minister Liz Truss says sorry after her chancellor tears up almost all of her tax-cutting agenda. Also: UN chief says Ethiopia war is spiralling out of control, and the BBC at 100.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine says Kyiv attacked by 'kamikaze drones'
item.description: Three people have been killed, including a pregnant woman. Also: the UK's new finance minister ditches almost all of the government's new tax cuts, and members of the K-pop band BTS swap their microphones for military fatigues.
item.itunes:subtitle: Three people have been killed in the capital
item.itunes:summary: Three people have been killed, including a pregnant woman. Also: the UK's new finance minister ditches almost all of the government's new tax cuts, and members of the K-pop band BTS swap their microphones for military fatigues.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Tigrayan rebels call for 'immediate' ceasefire
item.description: Diplomats warn that government forces could soon over-run towns and kill many civilians. Also; sources inside Iran's Evin prison say live rounds and teargas were deployed during the riot and fire there on Saturday night, and, could Mariachi music mitigate the progression of Alzheimer's?
item.itunes:subtitle: Fears that government forces could over-run towns and kill many of civilians.
item.itunes:summary: Diplomats warn that government forces could soon over-run towns and kill many civilians. Also; sources inside Iran's Evin prison say live rounds and teargas were deployed during the riot and fire there on Saturday night, and, could Mariachi music mitigate the progression of Alzheimer's?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: 'Big' fire at Iran's notorious Evin prison
item.description: The authorities said the blaze had broken out as a result of "unrest" inside the jail but was now under control. Also; Uganda imposes restrictions on movement in two districts affected by a worsening Ebola outbreak, and, after saying he will, Elon Musk now says he won't charge for usage of his Starlink services that are crucial to Ukraine's war effort against Russia.
item.itunes:subtitle: The authorities said the blaze broke out as a result of "unrest" inside the jail
item.itunes:summary: The authorities said the blaze had broken out as a result of "unrest" inside the jail but was now under control. Also; Uganda imposes restrictions on movement in two districts affected by a worsening Ebola outbreak, and, after saying he will, Elon Musk now says he won't charge for usage of his Starlink services that are crucial to Ukraine's war effort against Russia.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: British PM fighting for political survival
item.description: Liz Truss was hoping to restore confidence by sacking her finance minister and making another tax U-turn. Also; two brothers have pleaded guilty to killing the journalist, Daphne Caruana Galizia, in Malta, and, we pay tribute to the Harry Potter legend Robbie Coltrane who has died.
item.itunes:subtitle: Liz Truss was hoping to restore market confidence by sacking her finance minister
item.itunes:summary: Liz Truss was hoping to restore confidence by sacking her finance minister and making another tax U-turn. Also; two brothers have pleaded guilty to killing the journalist, Daphne Caruana Galizia, in Malta, and, we pay tribute to the Harry Potter legend Robbie Coltrane who has died.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Britain's Finance Minister is sacked
item.description: It comes after Kwasi Kwarteng was recalled from Washington for talks with the PM. Liz Truss is under pressure to rethink her economic plans. Also: what do we do with the billions of unwanted mobile phones? and we hear Freddie Mercury's vocals on a re-discovered Queen song.
item.itunes:subtitle: It comes after Kwasi Kwarteng was recalled from Washington for talks with the PM
item.itunes:summary: It comes after Kwasi Kwarteng was recalled from Washington for talks with the PM. Liz Truss is under pressure to rethink her economic plans. Also: what do we do with the billions of unwanted mobile phones? and we hear Freddie Mercury's vocals on a re-discovered Queen song.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Continuing protests in Iran four weeks after death of Mahsa Amini
item.description: Twenty-two-year-old Mahsa Amini died after being detained by the morality police for allegedly wearing her hijab improperly. In this special edition of the Global News podcast, Jackie Leonard, with help from the BBC Persian service, explores the history of women's rights in Iran. And with the protests showing no signs of ending, BBC Monitoring tells us how to verify footage of the demonstrations. We also hear a first-hand account of what it is like to be detained by the morality police, plus Iranians' hopes for the future.
item.itunes:subtitle: Twenty-two-year-old Mahsa Amini died after being detained by the morality police
item.itunes:summary: Twenty-two-year-old Mahsa Amini died after being detained by the morality police for allegedly wearing her hijab improperly. In this special edition of the Global News podcast, Jackie Leonard, with help from the BBC Persian service, explores the history of women's rights in Iran. And with the protests showing no signs of ending, BBC Monitoring tells us how to verify footage of the demonstrations. We also hear a first-hand account of what it is like to be detained by the morality police, plus Iranians' hopes for the future.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Trump subpoenaed by January 6th committee
item.description: Former President dismisses hearings, saying the committee is a total "BUST". Also; Britain's Liz Truss under fresh pressure as IMF criticism leaves many of her own MPs in despair, and, we hear about the restaurant for dogs.
item.itunes:subtitle: Former President dismisses hearings, saying the committee is a total "BUST"
item.itunes:summary: Former President dismisses hearings, saying the committee is a total "BUST". Also; Britain's Liz Truss under fresh pressure as IMF criticism leaves many of her own MPs in despair, and, we hear about the restaurant for dogs.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Global wildlife populations down by nearly 70% since 1970
item.description: Worldwide Fund says Latin America suffered biggest decline and blames human activity. Also: 39 people have now died in an outbreak of Ebola which began in Uganda last month; and the football from Maradona's famous Hand of God goal is to be auctioned.
item.itunes:subtitle: Worldwide Fund for Nature says Latin America suffered biggest decline
item.itunes:summary: Worldwide Fund says Latin America suffered biggest decline and blames human activity. Also: 39 people have now died in an outbreak of Ebola which began in Uganda last month; and the football from Maradona's famous Hand of God goal is to be auctioned.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Alex Jones told to pay $965m to Sandy Hook families
item.description: The conspiracy theorist is ordered to pay damages after branding the 2012 school shooting a hoax. Also: Nato countries to boost Ukraine's missile defence, and lab-grown brain cells play video game Pong.
item.itunes:subtitle: Twenty children and six adults were killed in the massacre
item.itunes:summary: The conspiracy theorist is ordered to pay damages after branding the 2012 school shooting a hoax. Also: Nato countries to boost Ukraine's missile defence, and lab-grown brain cells play video game Pong.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Crimea bridge attack arrests
item.description: Russia detains eight over Saturday's incident as NATO leaders meet to discuss more help for Ukraine. Also: TikTok profits from livestreams of Syrian refugees, Peru's embattled president faces fresh legal battle and the first discovery of microplastics in hailstones.
item.itunes:subtitle: Russia detains eight over Saturday's incident
item.itunes:summary: Russia detains eight over Saturday's incident as NATO leaders meet to discuss more help for Ukraine. Also: TikTok profits from livestreams of Syrian refugees, Peru's embattled president faces fresh legal battle and the first discovery of microplastics in hailstones.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine: Emergency online meeting of G7
item.description: Leaders warn Russia against using weapons of mass destruction. Also: as strike action continues at oil refineries in France, petrol rationing has been introduced in some areas, and in the UK Buckingham Palace announces the date of the coronation of King Charles III and Camilla, the Queen Consort.
item.itunes:subtitle: Leaders warn Russia against using weapons of mass destruction
item.itunes:summary: Leaders warn Russia against using weapons of mass destruction. Also: as strike action continues at oil refineries in France, petrol rationing has been introduced in some areas, and in the UK Buckingham Palace announces the date of the coronation of King Charles III and Camilla, the Queen Consort.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Russian air strikes hit Ukraine for a second day
item.description: The mayor of Lviv says four electricity supply stations were destroyed. Also: funerals take place in Thailand for those killed in last week's kindergarten attack; and the world’s first ultra-realistic robot artist gives evidence on whether robots pose a threat to human creativity.
item.itunes:subtitle: The mayor of Lviv says four electricity supply stations were destroyed
item.itunes:summary: The mayor of Lviv says four electricity supply stations were destroyed. Also: funerals take place in Thailand for those killed in last week's kindergarten attack; and the world’s first ultra-realistic robot artist gives evidence on whether robots pose a threat to human creativity.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Western allies pledge further military support for Ukraine
item.description: At least 11 people died in Russian cruise missile attacks on Ukrainian cities on Monday. Also: Industrial plants in Iran have been hit by strikes as hundreds of workers are reported to have shown their support for nationwide protests, and after more than 300 years without a leader, a Scottish clan chooses a new chieftan!
item.itunes:subtitle: At least 11 people died in Russian cruise missile attacks on Ukrainian cities on Monday
item.itunes:summary: At least 11 people died in Russian cruise missile attacks on Ukrainian cities on Monday. Also: Industrial plants in Iran have been hit by strikes as hundreds of workers are reported to have shown their support for nationwide protests, and after more than 300 years without a leader, a Scottish clan chooses a new chieftan!
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine: Kyiv and several cities hit by Russian missiles
item.description: Ukrainian officials say they've shot down 43 of the more than 80 Russian missiles. Also, Taiwan’s President Tsai Ing-wen marks the country's national day with a warning. And the head of Canada's ice hockey governing board resigns amid a sexual assault scandal.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ukrainian officials say they've shot down 43 of the more than 80 Russian missiles
item.itunes:summary: Ukrainian officials say they've shot down 43 of the more than 80 Russian missiles. Also, Taiwan’s President Tsai Ing-wen marks the country's national day with a warning. And the head of Canada's ice hockey governing board resigns amid a sexual assault scandal.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Special episode: Indigenous peoples
item.description: We hear from our Indigenous and tribal listeners around the world, as we mark US Indigenous Peoples’ Day. We also meet an Amazon tribe defending their land from illegal loggers; a Maori singer who makes pop music in his traditional language; Native American chefs bringing cultural foods to the restaurant scene; and more.
item.itunes:subtitle: We hear from Indigenous listeners around the world as we mark US Indigenous Peoples’ Day
item.itunes:summary: We hear from our Indigenous and tribal listeners around the world, as we mark US Indigenous Peoples’ Day. We also meet an Amazon tribe defending their land from illegal loggers; a Maori singer who makes pop music in his traditional language; Native American chefs bringing cultural foods to the restaurant scene; and more.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Putin accuses Ukraine of 'terrorism' on Crimea bridge
item.description: The Russian president blames Ukrainian intelligence for Saturday's explosion. Also: Iranian students lead anti-government protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, and we hear from the grandfather of the three-year-old who survived Thursday’s massacre at a Thai nursery.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Russian president blames Ukrainian intelligence for Saturday's explosion
item.itunes:summary: The Russian president blames Ukrainian intelligence for Saturday's explosion. Also: Iranian students lead anti-government protests over the death of Mahsa Amini, and we hear from the grandfather of the three-year-old who survived Thursday’s massacre at a Thai nursery.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine celebrates Crimea bridge blast
item.description: Russia's only bridge to the annexed territory has partly re-opened following the explosion. Also: People take to the streets of Iran in defiance of a security crackdown, as anti-government protests enter their fourth week, and the story of a 1,200 kg pumpkin that met a sticky end.
item.itunes:subtitle: Russia's only bridge to the annexed territory has partly re-opened since the explosion
item.itunes:summary: Russia's only bridge to the annexed territory has partly re-opened following the explosion. Also: People take to the streets of Iran in defiance of a security crackdown, as anti-government protests enter their fourth week, and the story of a 1,200 kg pumpkin that met a sticky end.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Russia 'preparing society' for possible nuclear option says Volodymyr Zelensky
item.description: The Ukrainian President made the comments in an interview with the BBC and called for pre-emptive sanctions against Russia. Also; the New York mayor declares an emergency, after thousands of asylum seekers were bussed in from Republican states, and, celebrating 60 years of the world's most famous spy on the big screen - Bond - James Bond!
item.itunes:subtitle: The Ukrainian President made the comments in an interview with the BBC
item.itunes:summary: The Ukrainian President made the comments in an interview with the BBC and called for pre-emptive sanctions against Russia. Also; the New York mayor declares an emergency, after thousands of asylum seekers were bussed in from Republican states, and, celebrating 60 years of the world's most famous spy on the big screen - Bond - James Bond!
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Nobel peace prize winners announced
item.description: The award goes to a Belarusian human rights advocate and two organisations in Russia and Ukraine. Also: banks in Lebanon will close their doors indefinitely after repeated armed attacks, and Ukrainians are braced for more possible attacks as Vladimir Putin turns 70 on Friday.
item.itunes:subtitle: The award goes to a human rights advocate and two organisations in Russia and Ukraine
item.itunes:summary: The award goes to a Belarusian human rights advocate and two organisations in Russia and Ukraine. Also: banks in Lebanon will close their doors indefinitely after repeated armed attacks, and Ukrainians are braced for more possible attacks as Vladimir Putin turns 70 on Friday.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Investigation ordered into Thai mass nursery killings
item.description: At least thirty-eight people died, most of them young children - the government says the whole nation is in grief. Also; Joe Biden pardons all Americans convicted of marijuana possession under federal laws, and, what does Scotland have to do with Pterodactyls?
item.itunes:subtitle: At least thirty-eight people died, most of them young children
item.itunes:summary: At least thirty-eight people died, most of them young children - the government says the whole nation is in grief. Also; Joe Biden pardons all Americans convicted of marijuana possession under federal laws, and, what does Scotland have to do with Pterodactyls?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Live special episode: Cost of living
item.description: The global price crisis. Our first ever “live audience show” – recorded in Malaysia. Listeners around the world and in the audience in Kuala Lumpur share their experiences and ask questions about spiralling costs and what can be done. Hear from our panel of BBC correspondents. What are the implications of the increases in food and fuel prices? How are governments and communities responding - and what does the future look like?
item.itunes:subtitle: The global price crisis. Our first ever ”live audience show” – recorded in Malaysia
item.itunes:summary: The global price crisis. Our first ever “live audience show” – recorded in Malaysia. Listeners around the world and in the audience in Kuala Lumpur share their experiences and ask questions about spiralling costs and what can be done. Hear from our panel of BBC correspondents. What are the implications of the increases in food and fuel prices? How are governments and communities responding - and what does the future look like?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Special episode: Abortion rights around the world
item.description:
In June, the US Supreme Court overruled Roe v Wade and ended the constitutional right to abortion in America. In a special episode, we investigate the changing dynamic of abortion rights globally in countries like Colombia, China and Ireland. We'll also be examining the restrictions still faced by women in Africa and places like Malta and El Salvador.
Audio for this episode was updated on 4 July 2022, due to a factual error in an earlier version.
item.itunes:subtitle: We investigate the changing dynamic of abortion rights globally
item.itunes:summary:
In June, the US Supreme Court overruled Roe v Wade and ended the constitutional right to abortion in America. In a special episode, we investigate the changing dynamic of abortion rights globally in countries like Colombia, China and Ireland. We'll also be examining the restrictions still faced by women in Africa and places like Malta and El Salvador.
Audio for this episode was updated on 4 July 2022, due to a factual error in an earlier version.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Young voices special
item.description:
Is the nuclear threat real? What does Putin want? Who is winning the war in Ukraine? We took questions on the invasion from young people around the world and looked for answers from BBC correspondents.
Jackie Leonard speaks to Martin Forster, a senior child psychologist with the healthcare company, Kry, in Sweden. Listeners' questions are tackled by Vitaliy Shevchenko, Paul Adams, Theo Leggett, Lyse Doucet and Mark Lowen.
item.itunes:subtitle: We took questions on Ukraine from young people around the world
item.itunes:summary:
Is the nuclear threat real? What does Putin want? Who is winning the war in Ukraine? We took questions on the invasion from young people around the world and looked for answers from BBC correspondents.
Jackie Leonard speaks to Martin Forster, a senior child psychologist with the healthcare company, Kry, in Sweden. Listeners' questions are tackled by Vitaliy Shevchenko, Paul Adams, Theo Leggett, Lyse Doucet and Mark Lowen.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Special: Global News Ukrainecast part 2
item.description:
A month since the Russian invasion of Ukraine, we are collaborating with Ukrainecast again. We answer more of your questions.
Jackie Leonard, presenter of the Global News Podcast, alongside Gabriel Gatehouse and Vitaliy Shevchenko from Ukrainecast, guide us through questions about civilian life in the country, military tactics, and the international response to the invasion.
BBC chief international correspondent, Lyse Doucet, joins us from Kyiv to talk through what is happening on the ground there, and BBC security correspondent Frank Gardner, tells us the latest on the physical and information war.
This episode was made by Chris Flynn. The studio director was Ash Taylor. The assistant editor was Sam Bonham.
item.itunes:subtitle: We answer more of your questions about Ukraine
item.itunes:summary:
A month since the Russian invasion of Ukraine, we are collaborating with Ukrainecast again. We answer more of your questions.
Jackie Leonard, presenter of the Global News Podcast, alongside Gabriel Gatehouse and Vitaliy Shevchenko from Ukrainecast, guide us through questions about civilian life in the country, military tactics, and the international response to the invasion.
BBC chief international correspondent, Lyse Doucet, joins us from Kyiv to talk through what is happening on the ground there, and BBC security correspondent Frank Gardner, tells us the latest on the physical and information war.
This episode was made by Chris Flynn. The studio director was Ash Taylor. The assistant editor was Sam Bonham.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Special: Global News Ukrainecast
item.description: BBC correspondents tackle questions from listeners around the world about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Jackie Leonard speaks to Gabriel Gatehouse, Vitaliy Shevchenko, Lyse Doucet and James Landale.
item.itunes:subtitle: BBC correspondents tackle questions from listeners around the world
item.itunes:summary: BBC correspondents tackle questions from listeners around the world about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Jackie Leonard speaks to Gabriel Gatehouse, Vitaliy Shevchenko, Lyse Doucet and James Landale.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Russia-Ukraine: On the brink of war?
item.description: Our experts in Moscow, Kyiv and London answer your questions about the crisis.
item.itunes:subtitle: US President Biden warns Russia might invade Ukraine in February
item.itunes:summary: Our experts in Moscow, Kyiv and London answer your questions about the crisis.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Omicron versus the world: Your questions answered
item.description: As the Omicron variant spreads around the world and cases surge, BBC correspondents tell us how Covid-19 is impacting our lives, our businesses and our economies.
item.itunes:subtitle: The facts, the science, the politics, the economics and the myths
item.itunes:summary: As the Omicron variant spreads around the world and cases surge, BBC correspondents tell us how Covid-19 is impacting our lives, our businesses and our economies.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Afghanistan Special: Your Questions Answered
item.description:
BBC correspondents answer your questions about the Taliban's takeover of Afghanistan. We ask how did the Taliban overthrow the Afghan government so quickly? What now for human rights, the economy and international relations?
Photo:People on board an evacuation flight out of Kabul airport, August 21, 2021 Credit:MoD/PA Wire
item.itunes:subtitle: BBC correspondents answer your questions about the Taliban's takeover of Afghanistan
item.itunes:summary:
BBC correspondents answer your questions about the Taliban's takeover of Afghanistan. We ask how did the Taliban overthrow the Afghan government so quickly? What now for human rights, the economy and international relations?
Photo:People on board an evacuation flight out of Kabul airport, August 21, 2021 Credit:MoD/PA Wire
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Global News Brexitcast
item.description: We team up with the award-winning Brexitcast team to bring you a special update on what Britain leaving the EU means for you. You’ve sent us questions from around the world and Jackie Leonard puts them to the experts from the podcast that’s all about Brexit. There’s also cake, phew. Spread the word! #GlobalNewsPod #Brexitcast Find the Brexitcast podcast here: http://www.bbc.co.uk/brexitcast
item.itunes:subtitle: What will Brexit mean for you? We team up with Brexitcast to bring you the answers
